==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|つう|やく|しゃ|yomi=o}}

===Etymology===
Compound of {{suffix|sort=つうやくしゃ|lang=ja|通訳|者|tr1=tsūyaku|t1=interpretation|tr2=sha|t2=[[-er]], someone who does something}}.

===Pronunciation===
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|音読み|On'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[t͡sɯᵝːja̠kɯᵝɕʲa̠]}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|つうやくしゃ|kyu=通譯者}}

# an [[interpreter]]: someone who [[listen]]s to speech in one language, and repeats that content in another language

====Synonyms====
* {{ja-l|通弁|つうべん|tsūben}}
* {{ja-l|通事|つうじ|tsūji}}
* {{ja-l|通訳|つうやく|tsūyaku}}
* {{ja-l|通訳人|つうやくにん|tsūyakunin}}

====Usage notes====
Although the term {{m|ja|通訳|tr=tsūyaku}} can mean both {{m|en|interpretation}} and {{m|en|interpreter}} (the person doing the interpretation), the term {{lang|ja|通訳者}} (''tsūyakusha'') refers more specifically to the person.

The term {{ja-l|通訳人||tsūyakunin}} appears in more dictionaries<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>. The term {{lang|ja|通訳者}} (''tsūyakusha'') may have gained currency as a parallel construction to {{m|ja|翻訳者|tr=hon'yakusha||translator}}, for which there is no {{lang|ja|翻訳人}} (''hon'yakunin'') form.
